title: Ticket #3812: collector reporting duplicate ads
description:
See slot13 below:

remarks:
2013-Jul-30 13:57:11 by pfc:
I should add that at any given time this is happening for a few nodes. E.g., right now it's happening on six: 
[root@condor kickstart]# condor_status | fgrep Unknown
slot14@spice033.su LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      1.000 ?   [Unknown]
slot14@spice046.su LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      1.000 ?   [Unknown]
slot2@spice099.sug LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      0.000 ?   [Unknown]
slot13@spice100.su LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      1.000 ?   [Unknown]
slot13@spice119.su LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      1.000 ?   [Unknown]
slot20@spice119.su LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Busy      1.000 ?   [Unknown]

2013-Jul-30 14:02:49 by tannenba:
The collector hashes startd ads on a tuple of the classad's Name attribute and MyAddress attribute.

I think you were seeing duplicate entries momentarily because the IP address of that machine (spice115) changed. Thus the ad with the old IP address for that machine will stick around until aged out.

Attached relevant lines grepped from the Collector log below showing the IP address changing from 10.20.3.115 to 10.20.3.84 right about the time you noticed the duplicate. As such I am resolving this ticket - we can reopen if I misunderstood something. 

07/20/13 08:14:06 StartdAd     : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.123 >"
07/20/13 08:14:06 stats: Inserting new hashent for 'Start':'slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu':'10.20.3.123'
07/20/13 08:14:06 StartdPvtAd  : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.123 >"
07/20/13 08:14:06 stats: Inserting new hashent for 'StartdPvt':'slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu':'10.20.3.123'
07/20/13 08:31:57               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.123 >"

07/20/13 08:31:57               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.123 >"

07/24/13 03:19:14               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"

07/24/13 03:19:14               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 03:19:14               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 03:19:55 StartdAd     : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 03:19:55 StartdPvtAd  : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 11:19:14               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"

07/24/13 11:19:14               **** Removing stale ad: "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 11:20:01 StartdAd     : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 11:20:01 StartdPvtAd  : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.115 >"
07/24/13 16:30:03 StartdAd     : Inserting ** "< slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu , 10.20.3.84 >"
07/24/13 16:30:03 stats: Inserting new hashent for 'Start':'slot13@spice115.sugar.phy.syr.edu':'10.20.3.84'

2013-Jul-30 14:05:26 by pfc:
That's a bug -- there is /no way/ these hosts' IP addresses are changing. From where does Condor get its idea to the contrary?

2013-Jul-30 14:08:08 by pfc:
...and I've just confirmed by looking at the hosts that their IPs have not changed (I can see the DHCP leases renewing and they're 100% consistent).

Could Condor be thinking one slot's update is from another?

2013-Jul-30 14:25:00 by tannenba:
It could be that two machines, one with IP addr 10.20.3.115 and one with IP addr 10.20.3.84 both have inverse names in DNS of spice115.

On machine 10.20.3.115, what does /bin/hostname say? What does an inverse nslookup and/or /etc/hosts say? Ditto for 10.20.3.84 ?

2013-Jul-30 14:44:53 by pfc:
We have no DNS on our private network.

2013-Jul-30 14:48:46 by pfc:
To use a host on which the problem is occurring right now: 
[root@spice033 ~]# /bin/hostname
spice033.sugar.phy.syr.edu
[root@spice033 ~]# fgrep spice033 /etc/hosts
10.20.3.33	spice033.sugar.phy.syr.edu	spice033
[root@spice033 ~]# ifconfig br0
br0       Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:25:90:29:D0:AA
          inet addr:10.20.3.33  Bcast:10.255.255.255  Mask:255.0.0.0
          inet6 addr: fe80::225:90ff:fe29:d0aa/64 Scope:Link
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          RX packets:4564387751 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:2398078357 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:0
          RX bytes:6107607130095 (5.5 TiB)  TX bytes:1419408916270 (1.2 TiB)

...and on the central manager: 

[root@condor ~]# fgrep spice033 /etc/hosts
10.20.3.33	spice033.sugar.phy.syr.edu	spice033

...so they all agree.

2013-Jul-30 14:56:09 by tannenba:
And what about the other IP address that was reported to the collector as spice033 ? Look at the 'stale' duplicate ad for the stale IP address, or grep 'spice033' at the tail of the collector log to find the other IP address. What other machine is using this stale IP address? How long has it been using it?

2013-Jul-30 15:18:51 by pfc:
Same thing. Consistent IP for months via DHCP, accurate hosts file entries, etc.

2013-Jul-30 15:20:09 by pfc:
I.e., the other host (spice144, aka 10.20.3.144) has not been using spice033's name or IP (10.20.3.33) at all, ever, period. And visa-versa. Evidence of this problem is 100% nonexistent outside of Condor's logs.

2013-Jul-31 14:20:08 by tannenba:
Another thought... does spice033 and/or other nodes that sometimes have dup ads have more than one physical interface? I could imagine a problem with duplicate ads if a machine has more than one interface with a route to the collector, and these routes have the same metric (weight) in the routing table.

2013-Jul-31 15:41:50 by pfc:
Nope, all our cluster nodes have a single physical interface, on our private network.
creator: pfc
